description:
Apis laboriosa, commonly known as the giant honey bee or Himalayan honey bee, is a species of honey bee found in the Himalayan mountain range. It is the largest known honey bee in the world, with a body length ranging from 18 to 25 millimeters and a wingspan of up to 40 millimeters.

Apis laboriosa is adapted to the harsh environmental conditions of the Himalayas, with its thick, insulating body hair and ability to maintain a higher internal body temperature compared to other honey bee species. These bees are known for their impressive nest structures, which can reach up to 2 meters in diameter and are typically built on cliff faces or under overhanging rocks.

The giant honey bee is an important pollinator in the Himalayan ecosystem, contributing to the reproduction of various plant species. It is also a valuable source of honey for local communities, although its nesting behavior and large size can make it more challenging to harvest compared to other honey bee species.

Due to their specialized habitat and sensitivity to environmental changes, Apis laboriosa populations are considered vulnerable in some regions. Conservation efforts, including the protection of their natural nesting sites, are crucial for ensuring the continued survival of this remarkable honey bee species.
